title: Marketing: Products and Services Management
headline: Master the strategies for efficient brand management and products and services distribution in this free online course.
description: With this free online course, you will master the vital procedures for managing products and services successfully. You will study the product life cycle, four stages of market evolution and roles of a product manager. The systems for brand management, as well as commodities pricing and distribution models, will be covered. By completing this course, you will move several strides closer to becoming a successful commodity manager.

courseDescription:
Most product life cycles are portrayed as bell-shaped curves, typically divided into four stages. In this course, you will examine the stages of the product life cycle and why they are crucial to the overall strategies of a firm. You will learn about the different marketing objectives of a company, and why business goals should properly align with the stages of the product lifespan. You will also see why promotional objectives should differ at each stage of the commodity shelf life. You will consider how to stimulate primary demand for a product, and how to use selective demand and penetration pricing procedures to discourage competitors and imitators. The systems for handling brand loyalty will be discussed and you will be shown two strategies for managing declined merchandise sales. You will discover the four stages of market evolution, and why firms must visualize a market’s evolutionary footprint to decide the limiting factors. You will consider how product managers expertly adopt category development and brand development indexes for supplementing data that relates to merchandising and brands. The strategies for market modification, brand and customer experience management as well as the four common techniques for commodities pricing will be explained. The course also outlines the three crucial steps marketing managers adopt when setting the prices of commodities.

Next, you will find out why marketing channels of distribution are considered as important pipelines for successful value delivery. You will consider the facilitating, logistical and transactional functions performed by market intermediaries, and will see how consumers can sometimes benefit from the activities of "middlemen”. The various distribution channels for consumer and business products and services will be examined, and you will study how interactive electronic technology can be harnessed for distributing services. Other contemporary distribution models, including direct and multichannel systems, vertical marketing (also known as service-sponsored retail franchise) and strategic channel alliances, will be explained. You will dissect the three vital factors that affect channel choice and management, and the three degrees of distribution density. The course outlines logistics and supply chain management, including the difference between the concepts of total logistic costs and customer service. Then, you will observe the key roles of the supply chain managers and how they balance the four customer service elements against the total logistic cost factors.

Finally, you will identify the importance of time (also known as the order cycle or replenish time for an item), dependability, convenience and communications in the role of a logistics management professional. The concepts of reverse logistics in modern supply chain management will be interpreted. You will be shown the consumer utilities offered by retailing, and you will discover how to classify retail outlets using the forms of ownership, levels of service and the type of merchandise line. The six forms of non-store retailing will also be highlighted. Is effective communication really an important retailing strategy? Is the retailing nature a static or dynamic phenomenon? This course will examine these subjects and consider the facts that surround them. Whether you are a product and service manager, business analyst or sales professional, by completing this course, you will have the sought-after technical knowledge that would help to increase your productivity. So why wait? Start this course today!

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this certificate course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this certificate course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison certificate is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital certificate: a downloadable certificate in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked certificate, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked certificate in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All certificate are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison certificate, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison certificate, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our certificate pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will examine the four important stages of the product life cycle. You will learn how the product manager leads a firm’s marketing program and executes analysis and supplementation of data. You will study branding and brand management, products packaging and labelling, and services management. Four vital pricing approaches for setting commodity prices will be considered. Then, you will see how to identify the pricing objectives and constraints that limit profits.
topics: Commodities Management and Distribution - Learning Outcomes
Commodities Management and Distribution - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will consider different marketing channels including electronic, multichannel, and vertical marketing systems. You will see the methods for managing channel relationships for conflicts resolution and business partnerships. You will study logistics management in the supply chain, the types of consumer utilities in retailing, and the techniques for classifying merchandise line of retail outlets. Likewise, the retailing life cycle and wholesaling strategies will be dissected.

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Explain the product life cycle stages and management techniques
    • Discuss branding strategies and brand management systems
    • Describe product packaging and labelling, plus the functional benefits
    • Explain the process of service marketing management
    • Discuss general pricing approaches, nature of marketing channels, and the importance of controlling costs

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are:
  • Product life cycle is portrayed as a bell-shaped curve, typically divided into four stages:
    1. Introduction stage – This stage occurs when a product is introduced to its intended target market.
    2. Growth stage - This stage is characterized by a rapid increase in sales.
    3. Maturity stage - The marketing attraction in the maturity stage is often directed towards holding market share through further product differentiation and finding new buyers.
    4. Decline stage - Occurs when product sales drop.
  • A company handles a declining sales of product via two strategies:
    1. Deletion - This implies dropping the product from the company's product line.
    2. Harvesting - This is when a company retains the production of a product but reduces marketing costs.

  • A company handles a declining sales of product via two strategies:
    1. Deletion - This implies dropping the product from the company's product line.
    2. Harvesting - This is when a company retains the production of a product but reduces marketing costs.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Identify the functions and benefits of intermediaries in marketing channels
    • State the factors that affect marketing channel choice and management
    • Explain the synergy between distribution management and marketing strategy
    • Classify retail outlets, and discuss vital retailing and wholesaling management strategies

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are:
  • Marketing Channel - It consists of individuals and firms involved in the process of making a product or service available for use or consumption by consumers or industrial users.

    Intermediaries - make possible the flow of products from producers to ultimate consumers by performing logistical, transactional and facilitating functions.
  • The most common marketing channels for consumer products and services are:
    • Channel A - Is a subcategory of a direct channel between the producer and the ultimate consumers.
    • Channels B, C, D - are subcategories of the indirect channel because intermediaries are involved between producers and consumers, and these intermediaries perform numerous channel functions.
  • Electronic marketing channels - Interactive technology has made possible electronic marketing channels, which employ the internet to make products and services available for consumption or use by consumers or organizational buyers.

    Vertical marketing systems - Are professionally managed and centrally coordinated marketing systems designed to achieve channel economies and maximum marketing impact.
